body:
We should also explore SO_REUSEPORT and forking a bunch of Ruby processes.
At some point we're going to be bound by the GIL for throughput.

On Thu, Mar 31, 2016 at 3:08 PM Vijay Pai notifications@github.com wrote:

> The current Ruby implementation is synchronous both in its own accesses
> and in its interactions with core. Any job that needs concurrency needs to
> use lots of threads. This leads to performance limitations as well as
> excessive core entry points (though, in fairness, the Ruby wrapping layer
> is quite lightweight and has better performance than many other wrapping
> languages). Here are some suggestions for performance improvement:
> 
>    1.
> 
>    Interact with core asynchronously. Rather than having individual Ruby
>    client/server threads interact with core through cq_pluck, have a single
>    Ruby thread act as the core interactor and let it use cq_next. Ruby threads
>    that currently wait on cq_pluck will instead wait on a cond-var to be set
>    by the interactor thread. No API impact.
>    2.
> 
>    Add an asynchronous server API. In practice, scalability is more of an
>    issue for the server API, especially if there is an intention to have
>    long-running operations like streams. If Ruby servers could directly
>    interact with a CQ (a Ruby wrapper around the core CQ like in #1
>    https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/1) there might be advantages.
>    3.
> 
>    !!:gs/server/client/
> 
> Thoughts?
